title: Back in his home town, Nationals star Anthony Rendon praises what Astros have done for Houston
text:
CLOSE SportsPulse: The Houston Astros are returning to the World Series for the second time in three years after defeating the Yankees, but must go through a red-hot Nationals team if they want to hoist the trophy. USA TODAY

HOUSTON – The spotlight and Anthony Rendon have a way of avoiding each other.

Monday, on the eve of his first World Series game, in the town that groomed him for this stage, Rendon had little choice.

And so the Washington Nationals’ All-Star third baseman basked in the glow, letting his personality shine for the entirety of a 45-minute news media session before the team worked out at Minute Maid Park.

Nearly every response was punctuated by a giggle, often fueled by Rendon himself, such as when he noted slugger Juan Soto’s propensity for grabbing his crotch between pitches. He called himself a “Redskin for life,” before noting that his alma mater, Lamar High School, eventually changed its mascot to the Texans (unlike the pro team near his current place of employment).

And above all, Rendon exuded grace, not just for this opportunity but also his opponent – a Houston Astros franchise he followed as a youth, with future Hall of Famers Craig Biggio and Jeff Bagwell his guys.

'PARANOIA': Astros, Nationals will keep a close eye on each other

The current group? Oh, he’ll work out this winter with Astros center fielder and perennial postseason hero George Springer, and they’ll surely have plenty to discuss.

Rendon is also appreciative that Springer and Co. brought the 2017 World Series title back to Houston less than two months after Hurricane Harvey devastated the region.

“They’ve all been tremendous,” he said of an Astros team back for its second Fall Classic in three years. “What they’ve done for this city – they’ve elevated the morale of this city, especially when natural disasters come hit this way and bring a lot of devastation.

“The fact they’ve brought so many spirits into a positive light – I love all those guys for what they’ve done for the city.”

Anthony Rendon speaks to the media on Monday at Minute Maid Park. (Photo: Erik Williams, USA TODAY Sports)

He termed this scenario “definitely a case of mixed emotions,” in that he’s competing for the game’s ultimate prize against the town that made him what he was, from the classmates at Lamar who welcomed him with open arms when he transferred before his junior year, to his years at Rice University, where he polished off the skills that made him a Golden Spikes semifinalist and the sixth overall pick of the Nationals in 2011.

Now, he has a lot of love for both sides – yet for at least another 10 days, there’s little doubt where the pending free agent’s loyalties ultimately lie.

“You think about playing for the hometown team growing up – that’s kind of a best-case scenario,” he says, “but in the end, I’m just trying to beat who’s on the other side. I don’t care who you are.”
description: Rendon, who grew up near Houston and played college ball at Rice, won't soon forget what the Astros did for the city after a devastating hurricane.
